headline: Oscar Piastri Returns From Summer Break With Pole Position, Stroll Crashes Twice
body:
In a spectacular effort, Oscar Piastri has squeaked past Lando Norris to take pole position at this weekend's Dutch Grand Prix by a margin of just twelve thousandths. With that lap, Piastri also breaks the all-time lap record set by Max Verstappen in 2021 with a 1:08.662.

Although Alonso looked very promising throughout free practice, he qualified tenth while teammate Lance Stroll went for two excursions into the barriers, ultimately ending his weekend before it even began.

headline: "I'm a real site now!": michaelscybersite.net Moves to Dedicated Web Host
body:
Over the past couple of days, I've been in the process of migrating this website from GitHub Pages to a new host, DigitalOcean. I've had a blast working on this site for almost a year now, and I'm looking forward to expanding and experimenting with it more now that I've got more capability in the backend.

It's a world of endless possibilities! Who knows what's in store—an internet radio station? A themed weather-widget? Web-GL games? A visitor counter? All sorts of shenanigans will be unleashed!

headline: Blue Jays Return to Top AL-East, Face Off Against Best Team in Baseball Next
body: After an amazing run this 2025 season, the Toronto Blue Jays have returned to the top of the AL-East after a stressful 9–8 win over the Twins. The Jays have been in fine form offensively as of late, but have reminded me why they're so often called "The Blow Jays"—once the starter steps off the mound, their defense falls apart.

headline: Lamborghini Pulls Plug on SC63
body:
In a press release, Lamborghini announced they'll be putting the SC63 Hypercar project "on hold" for a "strategic realignment" in 2026—after pulling out of WEC for the 2025 season, this stinks like a hypercar being murdered in cold blood. Sure, the car wasn't the fastest in it's debut season last year, but there have been flashes of potential as recently as Watkins Glen 2025 this past June.

It's a disappointing outcome and a short, troubled run for such a beautiful car.

Photo taken by me, Watkins Glen 2024.

headline: Oscar Piastri Wins In Belgium As Lando Falters
body:
After a lengthy rain delay, Oscar Piastri wasted no time in getting by Lando Norris to take the lead of this year's Belgian Grand Prix. The mistake at turn one which allowed Oscar to get by before the end of the Kemmel Straight was just one of many slip-ups which prevented Norris from taking the win today.

Lewis Hamilton drove a brilliant race, starting from the pit lane and finishing behind Alex Albon in 7th—I do hope we see this version of him out on track more often. For Alonso, it's a week to forget.

Going into the last race before the summer break, Piastri has a 16-point lead over Norris, and I reckon it'll only grow.

headline: 07/25/2025: The Most Beautiful Day In All of Existence
body:
We have just lived through (numerically) the most beautiful day in all of existence.

Two zeroes, a seven, three twos and two fives—just marvelous! And in this order, too! We'll never have another day like this for the rest of history. Two twenty-fives—two quarters! It just looks so good no matter what font you put it in: it feels good to write; it feels good to see; it is good.

A bit of a silly thing, but I think it's the most beautiful day in all of existence—but what can I say? I'm just a guy who likes 2's, 5's and 7's.

headline: Roger Waters: This Is Not A Drill Hits Theatres
body:
Featuring a full concert from his recent 2023 performance in Prague, this film really makes you feel like you're a part of the concert. Roger Waters hasn't lost any edge in his advanced age, and I'm glad to see he's still playing passionately. It was very cool to hear his little excerpts here and there, selections from The Wall in full costume along with the latter half of The Dark Side of The Moon.

This concert film is screening globally today in theatres—July 23rd—with an encore on July 27th.

headline: Christian Horner fired by Red Bull after 20 years
body:
This morning, I woke up to news that Christian Horner, the longtime team principal of Red Bull Racing, has been fired by the higher-ups at Red Bull.

I'm very sad about this. I think Horner is one of the greatest team principals of all time, and I've enjoyed having him as a constant in the sport over the past fiteen or so years I've been actively keeping tabs and watching. I don't have much faith that Red Bull will recover from their slump going forward without him at the helm—it's going to be a completely different team. I think they're going to drift lost for a decade like McLaren did after they fired Ron Dennis.

I believe he was ultimately sacked because there was a shift of allegiance in the higher-ups at Red Bull. Maybe this is in reaction to Max having signed a contract with Mercedes, or maybe this is a last-ditch effort to prevent Max from leaving. Either way, it's a huge loss and the end of an era for one of Formula 1's greatest teams.

headline: Matt Cameron Announces Departure From Pearl Jam
body:
After a twenty-seven year run, Matt Cameron has announced he will no longer drum for Pearl Jam.

After the original dissolution of Soundgarden in 1997, Cameron joined the band and played on every album and tour up to their most recent effort, Dark Matter (2024). Previously, he also played for Grunge pioneers Skin Yard and was involved in supergroups such as Hater and Wellwater Conspiracy. Matt Cameron is one of my favourite drummers, and I hope there is more music from him to come.

Regardless, it's a good time to take a moment and appreciate all the music he's been a part of over the past forty years.

headline: Oscar Piastri Extends Title Lead as Norris Falters in Canada
body:
Although the race was painfully boring to watch—especially after watching almost eighteen hours of top-flight sportscar racing—the sixty-seventh lap of the 2025 Canadian Grand Prix delivered.

Norris, in a desperate move to overtake Piastri, decided he was going to be a lawn mower and went for a gap that didn't exist in the first place. He crashed into the back of Piastri, shredding his front wing and sending himself into the pit wall down the main straight. To me, it was like birthday, easter and christmas all rolled into one!

Oscar Piastri now has a twenty-two point lead over Lando Norris in the driver's championship

headline: FERRARI WINS THIRD CONSECUTIVE 24 HOURS OF LE MANS
body:
Oh, glorious day! The 83 Ferrari driven by none other than Robert Kubica has won the 2025 24h of Le Mans. I'm just overjoyed! Ferrari has won Le Mans for three consecutive years, and each of their hypercars have now finished first at the greatest race of the year.

This is a full-circle moment for Robert Kubica, who drove some spectacular stints over the past day in France. All the drivers of the 83 were absolutely perfect, and they deserved the win. For a decade Kubica was looked at as the tragedy, the never-was—but no longer. Prime Kubica never left, he just went away for a while.

headline: Ferrari Maintains 1-2-3 four hours into LeMans
body:
This year's 24h of Le Mans has been an exciting race as always. The Cadillacs have faltered and lost the lead to the Porsches early on, and the Ferraris pushed through the field to take the top three spots. Through two pit stop cycles, the 1-2-3 has reformed, and I'm rather optimistic at this point.

Anything can happen in in nineteen hours, but this is looking good.

headline: McLaren Unveils 2027 LMDh Challenger
body: McLaren unveiled their challenger for the 2027 24h of Le Mans this morning. The first thing which struck me was the very flat front, which reminded me of the Tipo 6. Just like the Genesis, there's some Ferrari-like tail action going on. It looks like a Dallara hypercar—nothing super-duper cool, but I'm happy to see it. It'll be great to have another car on track.

headline: Cadillac Front Row Lock-Out At Le Mans
body: Cadillac has secured the top two spots today at Le Mans hyperpole. My Dad absolutely lost it and is really hoping this is their year.

headline: Piastri Strikes Back, Verstappen Strikes Out in Final Race for Catalunya
body:
Oscar Piastri has won his fifth race of the year at Circuit de Barcelona-Catalunya in Spain. After getting pole position by the largest margin of the year thus far, Oscar kept the entire race firmly under control while the rest of the field squabbled behind.

Max drove a brilliant race with a three-stop strategy, but it all went downhill when he got called in to the pits after Antonelli's Mercedes power unit decided to announce a new Pope. Verstappen had no grip on the Hards, leading to a mistake on the restart and a whole shemozzle thereafter. I believe he was in the right with Russell in the original incident, but the second incident just looked bad from all angles.

Norris made mistakes, as usual, and that cost him a pole and win. I'm happy to see Oscar's championship lead extended once again. Never in doubt.

headline: Porsche Streak Ends In Tragedy in Detroit
body:
Unfortunately, the Penske Porsche and AO Porsche win streaks in the GTP and GTD Pro classes of the IMSA WeatherTech SportsCar Championship came to an end today, with the #93 Meyer Shank Racing Acura taking the win overall. Renger Van Der Zande made it back onto the podium to take second place in the #10 Wayne Taylor Cadillac, and the final step on the podium was taken by the #6 Porsche 963. The #7 Porsche still leads the standings by a huge margin.

AO Racing had a weekend to forget with a mediocre qualifying and two incidents during the race which saw them getting punted by other cars into the barriers.

IMSA Resumes after the 24 Hours of LeMans at Watkins Glen, which I'll unfortunately not be able to go to this year due to the tariff situation.

headline: Penske/Porsche Sweep Continues in IMSA at Laguna Seca
body:
The #7 Porsche 963's win streak came to an end today, finishing behind its sister car in second place in the Monterey Hills. Still, every IMSA race this season thus far has been won by a team Penske, and the #7's healthy championship lead grows further out of reach of the rest of the field.

AO Racing's No. 77 Porsche 911 GT3 captured yet another victory in the GTD class, extending a similarly daunting lead.

Sportscar Endurance Racing is alive and well, and all my favourite teams are winning—the only thing that could make this any better would be for Alonso to get his 33rd...

headline: Ferrari's WEC Dominance Continues At Spa, Next Stop LeMans
body:
It is with great joy I once again write of Ferrari's dominance in the World Endurance Championship. This weekend at the legendary Spa-Francorchamps circuit in Belgium, the #51 car drove home to victory ahead of its sister car.

These past three races have been some of Ferrari's most golden moments in racing for a long time. The next stop is LeMans, and while I hope for a third consecutive victory, anything can happen at La Sarthe. Forza Ferrari!!

headline: LeMans Legend Jochen Mass Has Passed Away Aged 78
body:
Sadly, Jochen Mass—1989 LeMans winner with Sauber-Mercedes and Formula 1 race winner with McLaren—has passed away today at the age of 78 after suffering complications from a stroke he had earlier this year in February. Mass raced with the great F1 teams of yesteryear such as ATS, Arrows and McLaren-Cosworth back in the 1970s before going on to sportscar racing in the 1980s. I'll always remember him as a factory Porsche driver and one of the great German endurance drivers of the 1980s.

In endurance racing, he won races with the legendary Porsche 956/962 before moving to Sauber-Mercedes in 1988, winning LeMans overall in 1989 with the C11. He went on to win at Spa with Karl Wendlinger and Mexico with Michael Schumacher before retiring with a whopping 32 world championship victories with Sauber-Mercedes, Porsche and Alfa Romeo—second in wins only to Jacky Icx.

headline: Oscar Piastri Extends Title Lead in Miami
body:
My favourite up-and-coming Formula 1 driver has won again this weekend in Miami, making it three straight wins and extending his championship lead over Lando Norris. If it hadn't been for that unfortunately timed safety car during the sprint race, he would've swept the entire weekend. I'm overjoyed to see Piastri back on the top step—it's truly a legend in the making.

I'm upset with Hamilton becuase of his behaviour this race. I knew this was going to happen—he just can't keep quiet and be a good sport. We all know Ferrari's strategy is bad, but you can't just call them out like that on the radio. He's not a true Ferrari driver who drives for the Scuderia, he only thinks of himself.

headline: My Nikon D40 Has Died
body:
After 18 years of service and 209,365 shutter actuations, my Nikon D40 has taken its last photo. Today, on a rock in the middle of a pond surrounded by dozens of Red-Winged Blackbirds, two European Starlings, five Common Grackles, a happy little duck (Mallard), a Double-Crested Cormorant, two turtles and a beaver, I pressed the shutter button and got 'ERR: Please Press Shutter Again'.

Over the past seven years since my Dad passed it down to me, I've taken 195,363 photos. While he owned the camera, it saw Kimi Raikonnen win the 2008 Hungarian Grand Prix and travelled all over Europe as he went on business trips.

headline: Pink Floyd at Pompeii MCMLXXII Hits Theatres
body:
The 4k IMAX restoration of Pink Floyd's legendary performance in the ruins of Pompeii had the first of its limited screenings in theatres today. It's a spectacular film showing the band at the beginning of their breakthrough era in the early 1970s. Between live performances of tracks off Meddle and A Saucerful of Secrets, there's rather cathartic footage of them in the studio recording The Dark Side of The Moon. Band members reflect on the use of machines and electronics in music and make a great argument against creative AI. In a similarly prophetic clip, they discuss the occasional 'minor' arguments within the band—tensions which almost certainly led to Waters' split towards the end of the eighties.

This was a most amazing experience and I'm glad I went. The film restoration was just stunning: motion pictures of this quality simply cannot be made anymore.

headline: Ferrari Take Home Win At Imola
body:
After an enthralling six hours, Alessandro Pier Guidi, James Calado and Antonio Giovinazzi have won from pole position at the 6h of Imola! Spectacular! I've got no words to describe how excited I am about this.

Everything I love in racing is just coming together right now: the #7 Porsche 963 and #77 AO Racing dominate in IMSA, Oscar Piastri is coming into his own and fighting Max and Lando for the F1 championship, and now Ferrari has won the first two races in WEC! I'm overjoyed! Forza Ferrari!!!

headline: Oscar Piastri Leads The Formula 1 Drivers World Championship
body:
After fending off Max Verstappen to win the 2025 Saudi Arabian Grand Prix, Oscar Piastri now leads the driver's world championship. He's the first Australian to do so since his manager Mark Webber led during the 2010 season, which I refuse to believe was now fifteen years ago.

I've been saying it for years: Piastri is going to be world champion. Could this be his year? It looks like Norris is his own worst enemy: he's struggling under pressure that he's created himself. Piastri is cool as a cucumber

headline: Christmas Comes Early: Norris Crashes, Piastri Battles Verstappen For Pole
body:
The neighbourhood knew the exact moment the F1 TV directors cut to Norris after he hit the wall becuase my Dad and I squealed rather loudly at the sight of it. Today's qualifying session saw the McLaren driver continue to struggle while his teammate delivered an astounding performance which rivaled the great Max Verstappen.

After trading fastest laps separated by the thinnest of margins, Max Verstappen came out on top and will start on pole position for tomorrow's grand prix.

headline: Ferrari Top Qualifying At 6h of Imola
body:
After an action-packed FP3 and an exciting qualifying, Antonio Giovinazzi has put his #51 Ferrari 499p on pole position at the 6H of Imola, followed closely by AF Corse's private entry driven by Robert Kubica.

In a six hour race, pole position is nice to have, but ultimately doesn't mean much. I'm glad the Ferrari's are fast this weekend at home in Italy, and it's always wonderful to see Gio putting in a special lap—he's on fire this season!

headline: Hyundai Unveils Genesis GMR-001 Prototype
body:
Today in New York, Hyundai unveiled their 2027 LMDh challenger which will run under their high-end Genesis brand in WEC and IMSA. The car uses the ORECA chassis and seems to take design cues from both the Genesis brand as well as existing competitors on the field—namely, a Ferrari-style rear wing and Acura/Alpine-style front wing.

I'm looking forward to seeing this thing on track. The Platinum Era of Sportscar Endurance Racing continues!

headline: Piastri Wins Again In Bahrain
body:
Oscar Piastri has won the 2025 Bahrain Grand Prix and become the first driver to get multiple pole positions and wins this season so far. With this win, he is currently the only Formula 1 driver to have a 100% pole-to-win conversion rate—a cool stat, but one that can't last forever.

I've been saying it since he was in Formula 2: this guy is going to be a world champion. It was clear over the past couple seasons that he's been learning a lot every race, and now he's really starting to shine. Piastri WDC 2025!

headline: Porsche Continues IMSA Domination At Long Beach
body:
The No. 7 Porsche Penske 963 is three-for-three this weekend after leading a Porsche 1-2 across the line at the Acura Grand Prix of Long Beach. It's quite rare for a team to dominate like this in a sport as competitive and unpredictable as sportscar endurance racing, but Team Penske seems to have it all under control. In the GTD class, AO Racing’s No. 77 “Rexy” finished first once again ahead of the No. 12 Vasser Sullivan Lexus.

I’m overjoyed to see my two favourite cars wining their classes—it looks like this will be not only a championship season, but a record-breaking one. This kind of success is completely unprecedented, especially as the BMW's seem to have gotten their act together.

headline: McLaren Announce LMDh Entry
body:
Thirty years after McLaren won LeMans with the F1 GTR, they've announced their intention to return to the World Endurance Championship and IMSA at the top class in 2027. We saw it coming, especially after IMSA president John Doonan said to 'expect announcements from the blue oval and the papaya people' during an interview at the 24h of Daytona.

The platinum era of sportscar endurance race is just getting better and better, with McLaren joining Ford and Genesis as the next contenders to line up on the grid after Aston Martin and their Valkyrie. The teaser renders for this car look a lot like the Cadillac V-Series R, and that's becuase it'll be using the same Dallara chassis along with Antura's Twin-Turbo V6. I'm extraordinarily excited for what's to come. Sportscar Endurance Racing is the best form of racing, hands down, and it's only getting better.

headline: Max Verstappen Takes Pole & Race Win In Japan, Sets Lap Record
body:
After a magnificent pole lap which saw Max Verstappen take the overall lap record at Suzuka from Sebastian Vettel, he has won Sunday's Japanese Grand Prix. His Q3 lap is being hailed as the best of his career, with Fernando Alonso piling on the praise for Max's performance in an underwhelming car. Max was somehow faster than Lando Norris for the whole race, and after McLaren refused to let Piastri through, he crossed the line in first place. This was Max Verstappen's sixty-forth win and the first this season.

Personally, I think this was the third consecutive race where Oscar outpaced Lando. They didn't let him past in Australia, and they didn't let him past this year either. It just doesn't make sense! I'm also very happy that its Max who is toppling Vettel's records; I'm sentimental about that era of Red Bull and Formula 1, and I wouldn't want any driver to replace Vettel in the history books.

headline: Oscar Piastri Wins Chinese Grand Prix
body:
Oscar Piastri crossed the line ahead of McLaren teammate Lando Norris and Mercedes driver George Russell today in a statement drive at the Shanghai International Circuit. After McLaren wouldn't let him pass Lando last week and wet weather sent him spinning into the grass, Oscar has rebounded and led the team this weekend while Lando complained about this and that behind.

I was overjoyed to see the way he handled the race. George Russell has been very consistent, so that's great for him. LeClerc did an outstanding drive with a broken front wing, though I suspect a broken front wing endplate isn't always a bad thing from the amount of times I've seen this happen. Stroll surprised me more than he ever has—a great drive from him, and a great drive from Bearman as well.

headline: Oscar Piastri Takes Pole In China, Sets Lap Record
body:
Earlier today in China, McLaren driver Oscar Piastri took pole position with a 1:30.641: a new lap record for the storied Shanghai International Circuit. Piastri is my favourite up and coming driver, and when Alonso retires, he's who I'll be rooting for.

It's great to see Piastri on top. I'm not a fan of Norris—I never have been—but right from the get-go in his F3 days, Piastri seemed like a guy I could get behind. This season, I hope to see Piastri vs Verstappen vs LeClerc for the title, the latter of which unfortunately doesn't seem all that realistic at the moment.

headline: F1 Legend Eddie Jordan Dies Aged 76
body:
Eddie Jordan, one of the big personalities of Formula 1, has died today. It's very sad to see one of the F1 greats going, especially Eddie Jordan. It feels so weird knowing that he's gone becuase he was so full of life; he's not what you'd picture when you think of a man in the latter half of his seventies. I knew he didn't have long left after announcing he had cancer on his podcast with David Coulthard, Formula For Success, but I was still surprised nonetheless.

The Jordan F1 team was awesome. When I think of a Formula 1 car, the Ferrari F2000 pops into my head along with the "Buzzin' Hornets" EJ10. It's great that he was so involved in the sport after he retired from racing and later on from team ownership.

Today, it was Jordan. Tomorrow, it might be Ecclestone, Stewart, Prost or Ickx.

headline: Nasr Leads Porsche 1–2 At 2025 Sebring 12h
body:
The #7 Porsche Penske 963 is two-for two in the 2025 IMSA WeatherTech Sportscar Championship after winning today at the Mobil 1 Twelve Hours of Sebring. I'm overjoyed to see my favourite car win again and for Porsche to be running so strong here in North America.

My favourite GTD Pro car—the #77 AO Racing Porsche 911 known affectionately as Rexy—crossed the line first in its class. I'm overjoyed to see that team doing well, too. They're so young, yet they've found so much success in their two years; I'm hoping this is the beginning of another championship charge for both teams.

headline: michaelscybersite.net is now live!
body:
This website is now live at the new domain, michaelscybersite.net! How cool does that sound? A dot net site...look at me now Mom!

Although this site has been on the internet in some form or another since September of 2024, it's been hosted at the default GitHub pages URL. It's a minor change, I suppose, but it makes things feel a lot more official. I've changed the site logo to reflect this new domain as well.

Since a web domain is a nonphysical, abstract concept, here's a photo of my cat.

headline: Microsoft Publisher to be Discontined in 2026
body:
Microsoft has announced to Office 365 subscribers yesterday that Publisher will no longer be supported after October of 2026. While not many people (if any) really use Publisher anymore, I'm finding myself a little misty-eyed at the announcement.

When I was a kid, I played around with Publisher 2003 and made my own websites. You could say that it's only becuase of Publisher that this site exists right now, since that program was (oddly) my entry into web development.

You never really did live up to your potential, did you Publisher? But hey, fulfillment of potential is just an achievement in societal perception, and it's got nothing to do with personal fulfillment. RIP Publisher (1991-2026)—you'll be remembered, occasionally!

headline: Ferrari Finish 1-2-3 in Qatar
body:
At the 1812km of Qatar, Ferrari made history by sweeping the podium with their 499p hypercars. Antonio Fuoco in the #50 car was followed across the line by Robert Kubica in the privateer #83 and Alessandro Pier Guidi in the #51.

This was such a special thing to watch, and I'm so excited for the rest of the World Endurance Championship season. This is truly a platinum era for sportscar racing, and sportscar racing is truly the pinnacle of motorsport. Forza Ferrari!
